description.narrative: Scalable and sustainable innovations and strategies are identified and promoted to strengthen UNDP Country Programme delivery as well as to meet national development objectives.

activity-description.narrative: New sustainable solutions to challenging developmental issues will be formulated and scaled up in select states

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses.
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning.
3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.3 Engagement of the broader development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader development ecosystem.

comment.narrative:
Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 5 new sources of data per year 1.2 6 different type of data sources per year 1.3 35 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 5 innovation methods per Action Plan.
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1 At least 6 blogs or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector as counterpart 2.3 At least one government entity has adopted an accelerator lab method. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning. 3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network (48 interaction per year) 3.2 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Networks work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

OUTPUT 1
1.1 Five new Data Sources: i) Grassroot innovations as a source of data- horizontal knowledge sharing webinars were organized between Grassroot Innovation Augmentation Network (GIAN) and various other CO portfolios; ii) Soil moisture data for IoT experiment; iii) Digital chart of the world (Infrastructure data) and GADM (Database of Global Administrative Areas)for geospatial intelligence; iv)NFHS (National Family & Health Survey) for health data to map comorbidities; v) Agromarket data, HDI data
1.2 Six types of data sources: i) Qualitative ethnography data from GIAN, ii) Open data from government sources, iii) Sensor data from sensors installed in fields, iv) Satellite data for geospatial analysis, v) Weather data from local weather station, vi) structured big data (large scale national surveys)
1.3 The team identified and mapped 1500 grassroot innovation solutions and these have been made available through an open access database called GRID here: https://grid.undp.org.in/
1.4 The team used 6 innovation methods namely: i) Anticipatory regulation (experimental testbeds), ii) Challenge prizes, iii) Experimentation, iv) Innovation Mapping, v) Prototyping, vi) Gamification
OUTPUT 2
2.1 72 stories including 64 media articles and 8 blogs:
Example: ‘Swiping COVID-19 Myths Away with Gamification’
https://www.in.undp.org/content/india/en/home/blog/Swiping_COVID19_Myths_Away_with_Gamification.html and 64 media reports and articles in national newspapers.
Example of media publication: ‘Outlook UNDP India launches GRID for inclusive development’: https://www.outlookindia.com/newsscroll/undp-india-launches-grid-for-inclusivedevelopment/1983506
2.2 The team successfully established strategic partnerships with public sector entities (more than 80% of learning challenges) for most of its various technological pilots as part of the frontier challenges (air pollution, climate resilient livelihoods). Examples: jointly developed policy paper on ‘taking innovations to grassroots’ with NITI Aayog; Institutionalizing grassroots innovation with Telangana state innovation council, and frontier challenges - air pollution (Bihar and Punjab states environmental regulators), climate resilient agriculture(Spices Board, Government of Telangana)
2.3 One of the solutions scouted through the air pollution innovation challenge in 2019 was adopted by one of the local district administrations (Patiala district) in the State of Punjab. The pilot: ‘Usage of paddy straw-based biofuels for Brick Kilns’ was implemented by the Startup and the Accelerator Lab team in Nov-Dec 2020.
2.4 More than 70% of learning challenges contributed to CO projects. The team provided actionable intelligence to the following CO programmes: i) SDG State Outreach, ii) Climate Change (in the context of air pollution pilots), iii) Plastic Waste Management Team, iv) Inclusive Growth Portfolio (co-designed DEWI project using innovative methodologies in data science for social good) and v) Natural Resource Management
OUTPUT 3
3.1 a) Throughout the year, the team actively participated in the weekly global call and bi-weekly network calls between mappers, explorers and experimenters. Total: 44 global calls and 5+ 10+ 10 network calls
b) In addition to this, the India Lab also had regular learning sessions with multiple labs including Philippines, Sudan, Morocco, Gambia, Nepal, Vietnam. One such interaction and team-up led to the very first cross lab collaboration in the network. The Corona Champion game developed by the India team was adopted by Accelerator Lab teams in Morocco, Cabo Verde, and Timor-Leste and translated into their local languages. More info here: https://acclabs.medium.com/the-learning-network-effect-gamification-to-counter-covid-19-misinformation-india-morocco-cabo-cc88a5cafc7
c) One representative of the lab also attended 12 MOOC sessions that were conducted on the topic of: Mapping Inclusive Solutions for Social Transformation. During these sessions, there were several cross-lab interactions (40+ labs) and also solution exchange sessions between various labs
3.2 The lab members participated and actively contributed in the discussions on Microsoft Teams and Whatsapp groups (Total 3 groups). 60% of the information shared was linked to sharing opportunities and methodologies.
3.3 The team actively disseminated the work of the Accelerator Lab through Twitter, Linked in and Facebook. The total posts on social media tallied to 73 posts. The work was mentioned in 44 posts through UNDP India Social media Accounts (Twitter + LinkedIn) and 29 posts (Twitter + LinkedIn) from Personal accounts.
3.4 The work at the Accelerator lab was picked up on social media in 22 posts by other partner accounts that are a part of local development ecosystem. (Twitter + LinkedIn).

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 2 new sources of data per year 1.2 3 different type of data sources per year 1.3 20 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 2 innovation methods per Action Plan
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1 3 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector as counterpart. 2.3 At least one government entity has learned about Accelerator lab methods. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning.
3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network (48 interaction per year) 3.2 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 2 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

OUTPUT 1
1.1 i) Budget speeches for macro trends and ii) social media for public opinion on emerging trends 1.2 i) Citizen data through perception surveys of youth on air pollution, ii) Government open data for trends, iii) Geospatial data for potential use-cases 1.3 60 new solutions identified during the Accelerator Lab launch event- Date for development 1.4 Two Innovation Methods such as innovation challenge approach and speed dating for development conversations were tested
OUTPUT 2 2.1 15 media articles in total including 1 blog: ‘Stay hungry Stay foolish’ https://www.in.undp.org/content/india/en/home/blog/Stay_hungry_stay_foolish.html ; and 14 articles in national newspapers. Example: United Nations Development Programme launched Accelerator Lab in India to work on tackling pollution https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/undp-launches-accelerator-lab-in-india-to-work-on-tackling-pollution/article30108154.ece 2.2 Accelerator Lab worked with NITI Aayog (apex government thinktank) and Finance Commission (apex public finance authority) on national innovation policy – District Innovation Fund 2.0 2.3 Accelerator Lab India was officially launched on Nov 28, 2019 with stakeholders from government, donors, CSOs, academia, private sector and bilateral partners. It was launched by the key government partner- Niti Aayog. 2.4 One out of the two frontier challenge (50%)- Air pollution is also part of the portfolio of the Climate Change Unit in the Country Office (CO). The Accelerator Lab jointly organized an innovation challenge in December 2019 to scout solutions for air pollution. This work continues to feed directly into the CO pillar.
OUTPUT 3
3.1 During the first few induction months for the Accelerator Lab network (August-October 2019) the lab members participated in 2 bootcamps (2 Lab members attended a bootcamp in Rwanda + 1 member attended a bootcamp in Ecuador). Collectively, the lab interacted with 75% of the network in-person (45 out of 60 labs) 3.2 The lab members participated and actively contributed in the discussions on Microsoft Teams and Whatsapp groups (Total 3 groups). 30% of the information shared was linked to sharing opportunities and methodologies. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab team was onboarded between August-November 2019. In this duration, the lab’s work was featured 19 times by UNDP India Social Media accounts (Twitter +LinkedIn) and 15 times by personal accounts for a total of 34 mentions on social media. (Twitter +LinkedIn) 3.4 The work at the Lab was additionally picked up on social media in 11 posts by Other partner accounts that are a part of the local development ecosystem. (Twitter +LinkedIn).

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 10 new data sources per year 1.2 9 different type of data sources per year 1.3 50 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 10 innovation methods per Action Plan
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1 At least 8 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector as counterpart. 2.3 At least one government entity has adopted an accelerator lab method. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning.
3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network (48 interaction per year) 3.2 50% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network’s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 10 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

OUTPUT 1 1.1 10 new sources of data (I) Google Trends for key word analytics (ii) Social media data – facebook and instagram for Behavior Nudges (iii) Facebook Survey data on unpaid care work (iv) Vaccine hesitancy data from CoWIN platform (v) Spices farm-level survey data (vi) Indoor air pollution monitoring data from UBreathe (vii) Environmental non-compliance data generated by citizen scientists (viii) Grassroot innovations as a source of data (ix) Inclusion of Multi-dimensional Poverty Index (MPI) as one of the secondary data sets for assessing success of Covid Recovery Resilience Centres (CCRRCs) to be set up across India (x) International trade data on spices (APEDA, Govt of India)
1.2 Nine types of data sources: i) Qualitative ethnography data from GIAN, ii) Open data from government sources, iii) Sensor data from sensors installed in field, iv) Satellite data for geospatial analysis, v) Weather data from local weather station, vi) structured big data (large scale national surveys) (vii) Social media data (viii) Survey data (ix) Data from field experiments
1.3 The team identified and mapped 1500 grassroot innovation solutions and these have been made available through an open access database called GRID here: https://grid.undp.org.in/
1.4 The team used 10 innovation methods namely: i) Anticipatory regulation (experimental testbeds), ii) Inductive Case study research, iii) Experimentation, iv) Digital ToTs, v) Prototyping, vi) Social Entrepreneurship Bootcamp vii) Behavioral Insights Methodology (viii) citizen science (ix) Data collaborative (x) Sensemaking
OUTPUT2
2.1 - 11 blogs published in the year 2021 along with 70 + media articles (including op-eds, national coverage of Press releases and MoUs)
2.2 More than 50% of our learning challenges have government counterparts – including Spices Board (Ministry of Commerce & Industry), Department of IT&ES (Government of Telangana), Bihar State Pollution Control Board, Odisha State Pollution Control Board, Labor Department (Govt of Chhattisgarh), Department of Science and Technology, Government of India
2.3 The Geo-AI platform for monitoring air pollution from brick kiln industry was fully adopted by the State Government of Bihar through its regulatory body- Bihar State Pollution Control Board. MoU was also signed between UNDP India and the govt authority and was covered in 14 media stories. Example:
https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/patna/mou-inked-to-check-pollution-through-artificial-intelligence/articleshow/80773918.cms
2.4 More than 50% of the Lab’s learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. Some selected examples are: (a) The lab initiated a collaboration with GIZ India to jointly launch training workshops on voluntary carbon markets (VCM) for green startups and SMEs in India. During 2021, the lab delivered two training workshops on VCM for green enterprises in Kerala and Tamil Nadu States and over 100 green startups and enterprises were benefited from these programmes and gained knowledge on how to make additional revenue through VCM modality. This activity is well aligned with the Climate Change, Resilience and Energy (CCRE) Portfolio of UNDP India and add value to the ongoing work of CCRE portfolio. (b) The lab is promoting innovations related to Air Pollution jointly with the CCRE and SDG State Outreach Teams in various geographies across India. C) The lab is collaborating with Inclusive Growth portfolio to conduct policy experimentation through ‘Data for Policy’ initiative in Telangana.
d) Tapping into the Accelerator Lab Network, we captured International best practices in the area of Plastic Waste Management. Specific case studies from Vietnam and Phillippines are now documented in UNDP India-Niti Aayog publication- Handbook on Sustainable Urban Plastic Waste Management. This was a direct contribution to the Plastic Waste Management portfolio of the CO.
OUTPUT 3 3.1 a) Throughout the year, the team actively participated in the weekly global call and bi-weekly network calls between mappers, explorers and experimenters. Total: 40 global calls and 17 global network calls
b) In addition to this, the India Lab also had learning sessions with multiple labs more than 10 instances at regional level.
c) At least one representative of the lab also attended the final 3 MOOC sessions that were conducted on the topic of: Mapping Inclusive Solutions for Social Transformation. During these sessions, there were several cross-lab interactions and also solution exchange sessions between various labs
3.2 More than 60% of the information shared across the network was related to sustainable development issues, opportunities as well as Accelerator Lab methodologies. Some selected examples are:
a) Learnings from the Blockchain for spices initiative was shared widely with the network. Some of the learnings are also captured in UNDP Global Innovation Centre’s latest publication: “Blockchain for Agri-Food Traceability” in which the Lab was one of the contributing authors for the publication.
b) India lab also participated in a learning session with Jordan and Lebanon Lab on the topic of ‘Using BI tools for advancing gender equality’, this was conducted by the Innovation Team from the Arab States Region. In addition to this, it was also one of the 15 labs who participated in a workshop on: “Co-Creating a Framework for Supporting Systems Transformation at the Intersection of Strategic Innovation and Gender” c) The India lab is also actively participating in a regional project with Indonesia, Philippines and Bangladesh on: improving the internal user experience for the Knowledge Management System (to improve cross collaboration).
D) India lab has actively participated in Intel-Govt of India Digital Dialogues for senior policy makers on ‘Demystifying AI’ by presenting ‘GeoAI platform to fight air pollution’ along with UNDP Global Innovation Center.
E) India lab has shared experience on ‘Sensemaking for CPD’ with 15+ country offices in RBEC region.
3.3 The Accelerator Lab team’s work was featured 53 times by UNDP India Social Media accounts (Twitter +LinkedIn) and 103 times by personal accounts of all 3 Heads for a total of 156 mentions on social media. (Twitter +LinkedIn + Facebook)
3.4 The Lab’s work was covered in nationally popular publications/online platforms in India including Economic Times (ET) Edge Insights, Confederation of Indian Industries (CII) Food and Agriculture Centre of Excellence (CII-FACE) that are well connected with the broader Development Ecosystem in the country. The Acc Lab’s work covered in these platforms resulted in engagement with several leading practitioners in respective fields which further resulted in accelerated learning and sharing about the work of the Lab.

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
Indicator- 1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. Baseline: 0 Target : 5 new data sources per year 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used Baseline: 0 Target : 7 different type of data sources per year 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented Baseline : 0 Target : 25 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses. Baseline: 0 Target : 8 innovation methods per Action Plan.
Gender Marker: 1
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets. Indicator - 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) Baseline: 0 Target: At least 10 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners Baseline: 0 Target : At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite Baseline:0 Target : At least one government entity or partner has adopted an accelerator lab method. 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies Baseline: 0 Target: At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
Gender Marker: 1
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning
Indicator - 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs Baseline- 0 Target - 48 interactions 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. Baseline : 0 Target -25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. Baseline: 0 Target: Accelerator Lab Network’s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem. Baseline - 0 Targets: Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 10 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.
Gender Marker: 1
